contentrichtext.text: '''Zimran''' ({{Hebrew Name 1|זִמְרָן||"vine dresser; celebrated; song;"}} [[Arabic]]: زيمران), also known as '''Zambran'''.<ref>[[Josephus]], Flavius, ''Antiquities'', 1.15.1</ref> was according to the [[Hebrew Bible]] the first son of [[Abraham]], the [[patriarch]] of the [[Israelites]], and [[Keturah]] whom he wed after the death of [[Sarah]].<ref>{{bibleverse||Genesis|25:2-6|HE}}</ref><ref>{{bibleverse||1Chronicles|1:32|HE}}</ref> Zimran had five other brothers, [[Jokshan]], [[Medan (son of Abraham)|Medan]], [[Midian (son of Abraham)|Midian]], [[Ishbak]], and [[Shuah]].<ref>{{bibleverse||Genesis|25:1-6|HE}}</ref> [[Image:Jokshan-Zimran-Midian-ShuahMED.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Apparent and approximate emigration patterns of [[Abraham]]’s children by [[Katurah]], excepting those about whom not enough is known to draw a conclusion.]] Josephus tells us that "Abraham contrived to settle them in colonies; and they took possession of [[Troglodytae|Troglodytis]]<ref>In this case the word is applied to the cave dwelling peoples of the Rift Valley</ref> and the country of [[Arabia Felix]], as far as it reaches to the Red Sea."<ref>Josephus, Flavius, ''Antiquities'', 1.15.1</ref> Abraham, in all probability, tried to keep them apart from [[Isaac]] to avoid conflict while fulfilling God's commission to spread out and inhabit the globe.<ref>{{bibleverse||Genesis|1:27,28|HE}}</ref><ref>{{bibleverse||Genesis|9:1|HE}}</ref><ref>Josephus, Flavius, ''Antiquities'', 1.4.1-3</ref> For such reasons Zimran has also been tentatively identified by some with the Arabian town of Zabran, between Mecca and Medina<ref>''Seventh-day Adventist Bible Commentary, Volume 1'', Review and Herald Publishing Association (Washington, D.C., USA), 1953, p.367</ref> (that is, [[Jeddah]]<ref>[http://books.google.pt/books?id=VfqBeSc-TgYC&pg=PA165&lpg=PA165&dq=Zabran+between+Mecca+and+Madina&source=bl&ots=bOFpnu6DCN&sig=RlPevVtsoGEzAM3Re0qx8Sb3Zqg&hl=pt-PT&ei=kryoTcAlh4eFB92wpMUJ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CFUQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q&f=false The Edinburgh review: or critical journal, Volume 50], Sydney Smith, Lord Francis Jeffrey Jeffrey, Macvey Napier, Henry Reeve, Sir George Cornewall Lewis, William Empson, Arthur Ralph Douglas Elliot (Hon.) and Harold Cox, A. Constable, 1830, p. 165</ref>). According to the [[Sefer haYashar (midrash)|Book of Jasher]], the children of Zimran were [[Abihen]], [[Molich]] and [[Narim (son of Zimran)|Narim]]. Professor [http://www.gu.se/english/about_the_university/staff/?languageId=100001&userId=1911#tabContentAnchor1 Jan Retso] and [[William Hazlitt]] suggested that the descendants of Zimran are the same people known as "''Banizomenes''" which were mentioned in the records of the Greek historian [[Diodorus Siculus]].<ref>Arabs in Antiquity: Their History from the Assyrians to the Umayyads, Page 298</ref> <ref>The Classical Gazetteer by William Hazlit (1851), Page: 67</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} *[http://bible.cc/genesis/25-2.htm “Genesis 25:2”] ==External links== *[http://bibletools.org/index.cfm/fuseaction/Def.show/RTD/Easton/ID/3934 ''Easton's Bible Dictionary'':] Zimran {{Sons of Abraham}} [[Category:Torah people]] [[Category:Abraham]] {{Tanakh-stub}}
